{{weasel|date=November 2009}} '''{{lowercase}} {{Infobox software | name = iGoogle | logo = [[File:IGoogle Logo.png]] | makes your computer shut down | developer = [[Google]] | latest_release_version = | latest_release_date = | latest_preview_version = | latest_preview_date = | operating_system = | platform = [[Web browser]]s | genre = [[Web feeds|Web Gadgets]] | license = | website = [http://www.google.com/ig www.google.com/ig] }} '''iGoogle''' (formerly '''Google Personalized Homepage'''), a service of [[Google]], is a customizable [[Ajax (programming)|Ajax]]-based [[startpage]] or personal [[web portal]] (much like [[Netvibes]], [[Pageflakes]], [[My Yahoo!]], and [[Windows Live Personalized Experience]]). Google originally launched the service in May 2005. Its features include the capability to add [[Web Feed|web feeds]] and [[Google Gadgets]] (similar to those available on [[Google Desktop]]).<ref name="Mills" />
On April 30, 2007, Google renamed "Google Personalized Homepage" to "iGoogle".<ref name="Mills"> {{cite news | first= Elinor | last= Mills | title=Welcome to iGoogle | date= 2007-05-01 | publisher= ZDNet Australia | url =http://www.zdnet.com.au/news/software/soa/Welcome-to-iGoogle/0,130061733,339275160,00.htm | work = | accessdate = 2009-09-28 | quote = The search giant is renaming and adding new features to Google Personalized Home Page [...] iGoogle, as it will be called in a few hours, was the fastest growing product at the company last year [...] }}</ref> {{As of | 2007 | 10 | 17}} Google had made the service available in many localized versions in 42 languages, and in over 70 country domain-names.<ref name="Google blog">{{Cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2007/10/get-your-igoogle-in-42-languages.html|title=iGoogle in 42 languages|accessdate=2008-03-19 |first=Jessica |last=Gray |date=10/18/2007}} </ref><ref name="Google, Inc"> {{Cite web|url=http://www.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=20505&topic=9002|title=Google Web Search Help Center|accessdate=2007-06-17 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070312005013/http://google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=20505&topic=9002 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-03-12}}</ref> In February 2007, 7.1 million people used iGoogle.<ref>[http://techcrunch.com/2007/03/13/a-little-perspective-on-ajax-home-pages/]</ref> In April 2008, 20% of all visits to Google's homepage used iGoogle.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/business/article/0,8599,1736489,00.html | work=Time | title=Google's Art of War — With Facebook | first=Josh | last=Quittner | date=April 30, 2008}}</ref>
==Features== Google created the left sidebar feature to compress the size of the gadgets users want to have and to accommodate young chat users who are not interested in features such as news, weather, sports, financial markets, etc.
===Gadgets=== [[IGoogle Gadgets|iGoogle gadgets]] interact with the user and utilize the [[Google Gadgets]] [[API]]. Some gadgets developed for [[Google Desktop]] can also be used within iGoogle. The Google Gadgets API is public and allows anyone to develop a gadget for any need.<ref>{{cite news | first=Michael |last=Liedtke |title=Google dubs personal home page 'iGoogle' |date=April 30, 2007 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/18405212/ |publisher=MSNBC | accessdate=2008-07-25 }}</ref>
Google also allows all users to create a special gadget that does not require the use of the Gadgets API. The gadgets are designed to be shared with friends and family. The special gadgets must be created using an online wizard and must belong to one of the following types:
*"Framed Photo" â displays a series of photos. *"GoogleGram" â creation of special daily messages. *"Sidebar - designed for middle school chat rooms *"Daily Me" â displays user's current mood and feelings. *"Free Form" â allows the user to input text and an image of their choice. *"YouTube Channel" â displays videos from a [[YouTube]] channel. *"Personal List" â allows the user to create a list of items. *"Countdown" â countdown timer. *"Daily Literary Quote" â displays literature-related quotes served up by ModeRoom Press.
Some of the developer-made gadgets include:
*"Meteo-si": displays the current weather and the weather forecast for selected area(s) *"Ebay gadget": searches for items on [[Ebay]]
There is a "You might also like" gadget where you can look at similar gadgets you already have.
===Themes=== [[Image:Igooglee.jpg|thumb|right|iGoogle with the Winter Scape theme.]]
With iGoogle, users can select unique themes for their Google homepages: some themes designed by Google itself and others by the userbase.
====Artist themes==== In April 2008, Google began offering a choice of themes by professional artists.<ref>[http://www.google.com/help/ig/art/gallery.html iGoogle Artist Themes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Experimental iGoogle== On July 8, 2008, Google announced the beginning of a testing period for a new version of iGoogle which alters some features, including replacing the tabs with left navigation, adding chat functionality, and a canvas-view gadget for [[RSS]].<ref>[http://www.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=97658 Experimental iGoogle features]</ref> Users were selected for this test and notified when they logged in by a link to a brief description and further links to forums. On the forums, it was explained{{By whom|date=September 2009}} that there was no opt-out, as a [[Scientific control|control]] for the test. Further, there was no information on how long the test would continue. Many{{How many|date=May 2010}} expressed dissatisfaction with the new version and with the inability to opt out.<ref>{{cite |url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/09/01/google_personal_homepage_brouhaha/ |title=iGoogle personalises personal pages on other people's behalf |first=Chris |last=Williams |date=1 September 2008 |publisher=The Register}}</ref>
On October 16, 2008, Google announced the release of this new version of iGoogle and retired its older format. The release did not initially include the persistent chat [[GUI widget|widget]]. It does include the left navigation in place of tabs as well as a change to widget controls, however.<ref>{{cite |url=http://googlesystem.blogspot.com/2008/10/new-igoogle-publicly-launched.html |title=The New iGoogle, Publicly Launched |date=Thursday, October 16, 2008 }}</ref> The stated purpose is to prepare for [[OpenSocial]], with the new canvas view stated as playing an important role in that.<ref>{{cite |url=http://igoogledeveloper.blogspot.com/2008/10/big-canvas-big-opportunity.html |title=Big Canvas, Big Opportunity |date=October 16, 2008 |first=Jake |last= Quist |publisher=iGoogle Developer Blog }}</ref> ''[[InformationWeek]]''<ref>{{cite news | first=Thomas |last= Claburn |title=iGoogle Users iRate About Portal's Changes | date=October 17, 2008 | publisher=InformationWeek | url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/google/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=211201740 | accessdate=2008-12-16 }}</ref> reported "a vocal group of users" as unhappy with the changes, pointing out that many users do not want change forced on them, and that this is a general problem with cloud software under a service provider's control.
A workaround to restore the original tab layout was found by attaching "?gl=all" to the end of the iGoogle URL. On June 4, 2009, this workaround was eliminated. Within days, another workaround was discovered. Changing the URL ending to "?hl=all" would again restore the original tab layout, with some missing links across the top of the home page, including "Maps" and "more". This workaround was again eliminated on November 18, 2009. This led to an immediate resurrection of the controversy over user choice, both in the UK and world-wide, as many people unhappy with the new layout imposed on US users had switched to the UK Google site where the workarounds still worked. Within hours, the most frequently asked question on the help forum was how to restore the old layout, and there was a large number of feature suggestions to the same effect on the Google product ideas page. Other solutions have come to the fore, which require adds-ons, [[greasemonkey]] scripts or [[bookmarklets]].<ref>{{Cite |url=http://www.mark8t.com/2009/11/18/get-rid-of-left-navigation-in-igoogle/ |title=Get Rid of Left Navigation in iGoogle |date=Thursday, October 16, 2008 }}</ref>
==Removal of social features== On 14th October 2011, Google announced through its official blog that with its new focus on [[Google+]], the ability to interact socially on iGoogle will be disabled starting 15th January 2012, though iGoogle and its non-social applications will stay. <ref>http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/10/fall-sweep.html</ref>
